title: 106_hr583
content: The Act may be cited as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998" and addresses the treatment of Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act, known as the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998," includes amendments to the Civil Service Retirement System and the Federal Employees' Retirement System regarding the definition of a law enforcement officer to now include Assistant United States Attorneys. The Act, titled the "Assistant United States Attorneys Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 1998," amends the definition of a law enforcement officer to include Assistant United States Attorneys. The amendments involve adding an Assistant United States Attorney as a new category and defining it as an assistant appointed under section 542 of title 28. The effective date for this Act and its amendments is the first day of the first applicable pay period after a 90-day period from the date of enactment. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. "An incumbent, defined as an Assistant United States Attorney appointed before the Act's effective date, can elect to be treated according to the Act or as if it had never been enacted. The Department of Justice must provide notice of election rights within 6 months of the Act's effective date." An incumbent Assistant United States Attorney can make an election under subsection (c)(1)(A) before the 90th day after receiving notice, or before separating from service. No changes in retirement coverage will occur until the election is made. Service performed after the election will be treated according to the Act, while service before will be treated as per existing laws. Makeup Contributions: The Department of Justice must remit additional payments to the Office of Personnel Management under specific provisions of title 5, United States Code. These payments will be deposited into the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, including determining interest on required contributions. No individual liability is created for any contribution shortfalls under this Act. The Office of Personnel Management will prescribe regulations for the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund, including determining interest on required contributions. The term "Assistant United States Attorney" is defined as an assistant United States attorney appointed under section 542 of title 28, United States Code.
